title: How to Remove Iron Windows From a Cinder Block Wall

steps.headline: Gather the materials you need.
steps.description: Most items you'll need for this project can be found in any home with a well-equipped toolbox. Any other items can be procured from a nearby hardware store. You can find a full list of tools and materials necessary in the 'Things You'll Need' section below.

steps.headline: Unscrew the screws that hold the window cranks in place from inside the house and slide the cranks out of their position.
steps.description: You may have to wiggle them a bit to remove them.

steps.headline: Use cardboard and strong duct tape to cover and secure each of the window's sections that hold the glass planes.
steps.description: Be sure to use strong cardboard and strong tape to ensure that the glass doesn't fall out of the metal frame. Also take care not to cover the hinges or bolts that hold the window in place. Note that this step is not necessary to remove the windows and should be done at your own discretion and judgment.

steps.headline: Cut each of the top and bottom bolts of the hinges that hold the windows in place with the sawzall.
steps.description: It may be helpful to have another person hold the window so it does not fall when the bolts are cut.

steps.headline: Use the sawzall to cut the top and bottom of the bar that is remaining in the middle of the window opening and remove it.
steps.description: This flat bar will likely be vertical in the window opening.

steps.headline: Use the sawzall to cut completely through the window frame that is embedded in the cinder block halfway down any one side.
Bend the frame out of the cinder block gently using the crowbar so that you may continue cutting through the frame once you get to the cinder block.
steps.description: Be careful not to cut through the cinder block itself!

steps.headline: Repeat this step on another portion of the embedded frame that connects to the one previously cut.
steps.description: Only two adjoining sides will need to be cut and the second cut may not need to go all the way through, as the second cut is only to help pull the metal frame out of the block.

steps.headline: Pull the frame out in one piece.
steps.description: You might need the crowbar to bend the metal as needed.

text: Gather the materials you need. Most items you'll need for this project can be found in any home with a well-equipped toolbox. Any other items can be procured from a nearby hardware store. You can find a full list of tools and materials necessary in the 'Things You'll Need' section below. Unscrew the screws that hold the window cranks in place from inside the house and slide the cranks out of their position. You may have to wiggle them a bit to remove them. Use cardboard and strong duct tape to cover and secure each of the window's sections that hold the glass planes. Be sure to use strong cardboard and strong tape to ensure that the glass doesn't fall out of the metal frame. Also take care not to cover the hinges or bolts that hold the window in place. Note that this step is not necessary to remove the windows and should be done at your own discretion and judgment. Cut each of the top and bottom bolts of the hinges that hold the windows in place with the sawzall. It may be helpful to have another person hold the window so it does not fall when the bolts are cut. Use the sawzall to cut the top and bottom of the bar that is remaining in the middle of the window opening and remove it. This flat bar will likely be vertical in the window opening. Use the sawzall to cut completely through the window frame that is embedded in the cinder block halfway down any one side.  Bend the frame out of the cinder block gently using the crowbar so that you may continue cutting through the frame once you get to the cinder block. Be careful not to cut through the cinder block itself! Repeat this step on another portion of the embedded frame that connects to the one previously cut. Only two adjoining sides will need to be cut and the second cut may not need to go all the way through, as the second cut is only to help pull the metal frame out of the block. Pull the frame out in one piece. You might need the crowbar to bend the metal as needed.
